text: Freelancers! I'm starting with a new client on Tuesday to write content/help build out their website. When I was introduced to the person who is working on the analytics for the project they said to me: "I've worked with copywriters that have a very thorough questionnaire for the product owner in order to get a thorough understanding of the products/company before beginning the work. Do you do this?" I felt like a doof because, no I have no such "thorough questionnaire" as I was just going to talk to the owner, learn the company and then do a content audit to see what's up to get my bearings and learn the brand. However, I felt a little noob-like (which I'm not) But...is this something that I should be doing? Should I have a thorough questionnaire to send to the client to learn about the brand and the product? I'm more of a "do my own research and then ask questions to fill in the gaps."  But...I don't know...thoughts? Advice? What do you all do?

elements.text: Freelancers! I'm starting with a new client on Tuesday to write content/help build out their website. When I was introduced to the person who is working on the analytics for the project they said to me: "I've worked with copywriters that have a very thorough questionnaire for the product owner in order to get a thorough understanding of the products/company before beginning the work. Do you do this?" I felt like a doof because, no I have no such "thorough questionnaire" as I was just going to talk to the owner, learn the company and then do a content audit to see what's up to get my bearings and learn the brand. However, I felt a little noob-like (which I'm not) But...is this something that I should be doing? Should I have a thorough questionnaire to send to the client to learn about the brand and the product? I'm more of a "do my own research and then ask questions to fill in the gaps."  But...I don't know...thoughts? Advice? What do you all do?

text:
Hi <@U02CVNB3X1T>. I have never had to give a questionnaire to a client to learn about the product, but maybe that's just me. In this situation, my approach would be just like yours: Do my research and ask questions to fill the gaps. 
I think you should communicate with the person who works on the project analytics what your learning processes look like. If they are okay with it, then great. If they still want a thorough questionnaire, then you can provide them with one. 
However, I don't think you should start creating a questionnaire straightaway before speaking with the person first and letting them know that you will work better if you do your own research first and ask questions later.

elements.text:

I think you should communicate with the person who works on the project analytics what your learning processes look like. If they are okay with it, then great. If they still want a thorough questionnaire, then you can provide them with one. 
However, I don't think you should start creating a questionnaire straightaway before speaking with the person first and letting them know that you will work better if you do your own research first and ask questions later.

text:
Is the person working on the analytics a writer? Everyone seems to know the writer's job so well...except that they can't write.

Anyway, sending a questionnaire depends on what the client does. I'm assuming this is going to be a long term collaboration. If it is, you should speak with the client first before creating a questionnaire. Assuming the website is already up and running, you'd have looked at the website, check out the competition and draft questions based on that. But for a new site, you'll have to talk to the owner first.
